Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cloud-based analysis of mass spectrometry proteomics data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteins carry out a vast range of critical activities including signaling, DNA replication, gene regulation, immune response, etc. Tandem mass spectrometry is the only high-throughput way to characterize these proteins in complex biological mixtures. This project will produce algorithms with the potential to dramatically improve the ability of proteomics scientists around the world to interpret their tandem mass spectrometry data, thereby providing critical insights into these fundamental biological processes. Because proteins are the primary functional molecules in the cell, such insights are foundational to our scientific understanding of life.

The key intellectual contributions in this proposal lie in the development of novel machine learning methods for proteomics. Specifically, the project will develop novel methods for spectrum feature extraction, including deep neural network autoencoding and low-dimensional representation learning, learning deep similarity metrics that allow efficient spatial data access methods, applications of autoencoding for spectrum and experiment compression, submodular summarization methods on proteomic data, and classification and ranking methodologies that take advantage of network effects via a data embedding. These tools will then be used for proteomic metadata inference, cloud-based peptide and protein identification, and retrieval and ranking of similar proteomic experiments. The research will hence yield a profoundly more powerful, data-driven approach to jointly interpreting massive mass spectrometry data sets, thereby giving scientists valuable new tools to glean insights into protein function.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tandem mass spectrometry is the primary analytical tool used by the growing field of proteomics.  One of the primary bottlenecks in this field is the development and deployment of efficient, accurate methods to make sense out of the big proteomics data sets that are now being generated in hundreds of labs around the world.  This project developed several computational methods to address this critical need. One tehnique, called submodular generalized bipartite matching, significantly improves our ability to identify the biomolecules responsible for generating the data produced by the mass spectrometer. Software describing this method is freely available, and the manuscript describing this work won a Best Paper award at a major scientific conference. The second method uses a machine learning technique called regression to solve the same problem, but for a new type of mass spectrometry data called "data independent acquisition" (DIA) data. The key novel concept in our approach is that, rather than treating each peptide species as an independent query against a given mass spectrometry data set, our method approaches the inference problem jointly, querying a large set of peptides against the full data set. This approach allows us to properly manage overlapping signals ("interference") caused by peptides with similar mass characteristics.  We foresee widespread adoption of DIA technology, and our new method promises to provide improved statistical power to make sense out of this important class of data.

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2017
Modified by: William S Noble
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Tandem mass spectrometry is the primary analytical tool used by the growing field of proteomics. One of the primary bottlenecks in this field is the development and deployment of efficient, accurate methods to make sense out of the big proteomics data sets that are now being generated in hundreds of labs around the world. This project developed several computational methods to address this critical need. One tehnique, called submodular generalized bipartite matching, significantly improves our ability to identify the biomolecules responsible for generating the data produced by the mass spectrometer. Software describing this method is freely available, and the manuscript describing this work won a Best Paper award at a major scientific conference. The second method uses a machine learning technique called regression to solve the same problem, but for a new type of mass spectrometry data called "data independent acquisition" (DIA) data. The key novel concept in our approach is that, rather than treating each peptide species as an independent query against a given mass spectrometry data set, our method approaches the inference problem jointly, querying a large set of peptides against the full data set. This approach allows us to properly manage overlapping signals ("interference") caused by peptides with similar mass characteristics. We foresee widespread adoption of DIA technology, and our new method promises to provide improved statistical power to make sense out of this important class of data.
